prompt.p: A 56-year-old man presents with a 6-month history of lethargy and excessive bruising. He is known to have diabetes and rheumatoid arthritis and is taking steroids.
On inspection the patient has truncal obesity with a buffalo hump. He is noted to have thin skin with abdominal striae and pigmentation. A neurological examination reveals proximal muscle weakness.
From the following options, select the most appropriate diagnosis.

modalFeedback.p: Option C (Cushing's syndrome) is Correct. This patient is taking steroids which can lead to Cushing's syndrome. the clinical findings described are typical.
Option A (Acromegaly) is Incorrect. Patients with acromegaly have coarse facial features and an increase in the size of their hands and feet.
Option B (Cerebrovascular accident) is Incorrect. There is no history of change in vision or speech to suggest a CVA.
Option D (Hypothyroidism) is Incorrect. Hypothyroidism is not associated with truncal obesity or buffalo hump.
Option E (Obesity) is Incorrect. Simple obesity is not associated with excessive bruising and abdominal striae.
